3.3.1.title: Types of Rams
3.3.1.content:
**Pipe Rams:**
- Close around specific pipe size
- Rubber element seals around pipe body
- Must match pipe size in use
- Variable bore rams (VBRs) can seal range of sizes

**Blind Rams:**
- Close on open hole (no pipe)
- Two solid blocks meet
- Cannot close if pipe is in bore

**Blind Shear Rams (BSR):**
- Shear through drillpipe AND seal wellbore
- Can cut pipe and then seal
- Critical for emergency disconnect
- May not cut all tubulars (tool joints, heavy pipe)

**Casing Shear Rams:**
- Cut through casing
- Used in some subsea configurations
- Heavier duty than BSR

3.3.2.title: Design and Function
3.3.2.content:
**Operating Principle:**
1. Hydraulic pressure applied to close
2. Rams extend from both sides
3. Rams meet in center
4. Sealing elements provide pressure seal
5. Mechanical locks may engage for additional security

**Key Components:**
- Ram blocks (steel body of ram)
- Top seal (seals on top of ram)
- Front packer (seals around pipe)
- Side packers (seal between ram and body)
- Operating piston
- Hydraulic connections

**Locks:**
- Manual locks (operated by hand)
- Hydraulic locks (operated remotely)
- Secondary lock - provides backup to hydraulic closure

3.3.3.title: Pipe Rams
3.3.3.content:
**Sizing:**
- Must match pipe OD exactly
- Different rams for different pipe sizes
- VBRs accommodate range (e.g., 3-1/2" to 5-1/2")

**Sealing:**
- Front packer seals around pipe
- Top seal seals between rams
- Will NOT seal on tool joint

**Operation:**
- Cannot close on tool joint - position pipe correctly
- Space out to put pipe body across rams before closing
- Opening requires relieving wellbore pressure (or use HCR)

**Changing Rams:**
- May need to change ram blocks for different pipe sizes
- Time-consuming operation
- Plan pipe sizes and ram configuration

3.3.4.title: Blind Shear Rams
3.3.4.content:
**Purpose:**
- Emergency closure when pipe must be cut
- Last resort - cuts pipe in well
- Essential for EDS in subsea operations

**Cutting Capability:**
- Designed to cut specific pipe range
- May NOT cut tool joints, heavy wall, or casing
- Know the specifications and limitations

**Position:**
- Typically one BSR per stack
- Position allows cutting at any point except connections

**After Shearing:**
- Upper pipe free (falls or is held by slips)
- Lower pipe drops into well with tubing hanger or sits on rams
- Wellbore sealed by BSR

**Testing:**
- Function test closure
- Shear test may be done (actual or simulated)
- Pressure test after closure

3.3.5.title: Testing Ram Preventers
3.3.5.content:
**Pressure Tests:**
- Low pressure test: 200-300 psi (seal verification)
- High pressure test: To working pressure rating
- Test on pipe (pipe rams)
- Test on open hole (blind rams)

**Frequency:**
- Initial installation
- After each BOP pull/reinstallation
- At casing points
- Per regulatory requirements (often weekly low pressure, longer interval for high pressure)

**Procedure:**
1. Close ram
2. Apply pressure below ram
3. Observe for leaks
4. Hold for required time (typically 5 minutes)
5. Record results
6. Open ram, verify opens fully

3.3.6.title: Maintenance
3.3.6.content:
**Seals:**
- Inspect packers and seals regularly
- Replace if damaged or worn
- Keep spare seal kits on location

**Ram Blocks:**
- Inspect for damage
- Check blade condition (shear rams)
- Replace per manufacturer recommendation

**Body:**
- Inspect bore for wear
- Check hydraulic connections
- Verify bonnet operation

**Locks:**
- Test lock function
- Ensure manual locks accessible
- Lubricate as required
